symptoms.1: Yellow or chlorotic spots on leaves.
symptoms.2: Dark olive green spots on leaves and fruit.
symptoms.3: May be a velvety growth on spots on undersides of leaves.
symptoms.6: Severely infected leaves turn yellow and drop from tree.

comments.1: Fungus overwinters on dead foliage on ground.
comments.2: spores dispersed by wind; high moisture encourages fungal growth.

management.1: Remove all leaves dropped from tree in the fall and compost to prevent any diseases surviving in debris.
management.2: Application of zinc and fertilizer grade urea in the Fall may be necessary to speed leaf drop, lime should then be added to fallen leaves.
management.3: Fungicide application may be necessary in areas where leaves remain wet for periods in excess of 9 hours.
management.4: Fungicides such as copper soaps and Bordeaux mixture should be applied if there is a chance of wet period as soon as leaf tips emerge.

symptoms.1: Purple flecks or circular lesions which are brown in the centre and purple at margin.
symptoms.2: Red flecks, purple lesions and/or brown black rings on fruit.

comments.1: Spores can overwinter in twigs or fruit remaining on the tree and spread during rainfall.

management.1: Remove dead wood, mummified fruit and cankers from trees to reduce spread of disease.
management.2: Burn any prunings that have been made from the tree.
management.3: Disease can be controlled by applying fungicides from silver tip to harvest.

symptoms.1: Bright orange or yellow patches on top side of leaves surrounded by a red band and small black spots in the center.
symptoms.2: By mid-summer, cup-like structures called aecia form on the leaf undersides.
symptoms.3: These become covered in tubular structures from which spores are released.

comments.1: Fungus requires two hosts to complete lifecycle.
comments.2: Forms galls on Eastern red cedar and spores are carried by wind to apple.
comments.3: Use caution when planting apple close to red cedar.

management.3: If growing susceptible varieties in proximity to red cedar follow a fungicide program.

symptoms.1: Light colored circular lesions on leaves inside tree canopy which develop a powdery appearance.
symptoms.2: Lesions may coalesce to cover leaf.
symptoms.3: If infection is severe, leaves may blister and infected shoots may be distorted and stunted.
symptoms.4: Infected fruits may have slightly depressed areas on the surface containing fungal hyphae (filamentous fungal structures).

comments.1: Infection of fruit is more likely if there are rainfalls close to harvest.

management.1: Management of powdery mildew in cherry is reliant on the application of appropriate fungicides and cultural practices which promote good air circulation around tree canopies to lower humidity.

symptoms.1: Small necrotic spots with chlorotic halos on leaves which expand to rectangular lesions 1-6 cm in length and 2-4 mm wide.
symptoms.2: As the lesions mature they turn tan in color and finally gray.
symptoms.3: Lesions have sharp, parallel edges and are opaque.
symptoms.4: Disease can develop quickly causing complete blighting of leaves and plant death.

comments.1: Disease emergence is favored in areas where a corn crop is followed by more corn with no rotastion.
comments.2: Severity and incidence of disease is likely die to continuous corn culture with minimum tillage and the use of susceptible hybrids in in the midwestern corn belt of the USA.
comments.3: Prolonged periods of foggy or cloudy weather can cause severe Cercopora epidemics.

management.1: Plant corn hybrids with resistance to the disease.
management.2: Crop rotation and plowing debris into soil may reduce levels of inoculum in the soil but may not provide control in areas where the disease is prevalent.
management.3: Foliar fungicides may be economically viable for some high yeilding susceptible hybrids.

symptoms.1: Oval or elongated cinnamon brown pustules on upper and lower surfaces of leaves.
symptoms.2: Pustules rupture and release powdery red spores.
symptoms.3: Pustules turn dark brown-black as they mature and release dark brown powdery spores.
symptoms.4: If infection is severe, pustules may appear on tassels and ears and leaves may begin to yellow.
symptoms.5: In partially resistant corn hybrids, symptoms appear as chlorotic or necrotic flecks on the leaves which release little or no spore.

comments.1: Disease is spread by wind-borne spores.
comments.2: Some of the most popularly grown sweet corn varieties have little or no resistance to the disease.

management.1: The most effective method of controlling the disease is to plant resistant hybrids.
management.2: Application of appropriate fungicides may provide some degree on control and reduce disease severity.
management.3: Fungicides are most effective when the amount of secondary inoculum is still low, generally when plants only have a few rust pustules per leaf.

symptoms.1: In the beginning we will notice elliptical gray-green lesions on leaves. As the disease process this lesions become pale gray to tan color.
symptoms.2: Later stage the lesions looks dirty due to dark gray spores particularly under lower leaf surface.
symptoms.3: The disease can be easily identified in the field due to its long, narrow lesions which are unrestricted by veins.

comments.1: The disease mainly spread through rain splash and wind.

management.1: Follow proper tillage to reduce fungus inoculum from crop debris.
management.2: Follow crop rotation with non host crop.
management.4: In severe case of disease incidence apply suitable fungicide.
